There is a dearth of ecological data sets of any significant length  for  large pelagic ocean animals, except nesting beach studies for sea turtless.  They do not exist for highly migratory or pelagic fishes and marine mammals.

column33: Verifying Greenhouse Gas Emissions: Methods to Support International Climate Agreements
column85: Long-term data in many locations are critical for drawing conclusions, understanding the range of possibilities given the range of environmental conditions. Yet, we don't have sufficient long-term observations in enough locations with enough ancillary data to produce many syntheses of results that can diagnose causes of variation. New ecological programs will not have long-term data in time to produce baseline data for things like climate change and pollutants. Best to keep good existing programs running to extend the long-term record, such as the global CO2 observation sites.

column33: Advancing the Science of Climate Change
column79: We found that studies of 6+ years were not as common in the literature as shorter-term studies.
column85: Most of our citations were to high-level theoretical studies or to review papers and syntheses.  We had relatively few citations to primary observational studies.  Nevertheless, such observation studies are the foundation upon which the theoretical and review studies rest, so lack of citation in NRC reports should not be seen as an indicator of lack of importance. Their importance grows in aggregate as individual studies can be seen as being almost anecdotal. /  / Thus most of my answers are useless.  Long-term ecological studies are as essential as they are rare. Lack of direct citation reflects the demands of high level reports which are essentially summarizing review papers, and does not reflect on the importance of long-term ecological research.

column33: Eighteenth Interim Report of the Committee on Acute Exposure Guideline Levels
Ecosystem Concepts for Sustainable Bivalve Mariculture
column85: One particular issue in relation to citing references is availability and applicability of refereces to the field and subject matter. You basically have to go with what's available and sometimes the status/quality of the publication is not the best. This would certainly influence the confidence of the conclusions and the overall strenght of a report. Furthermore, as an aside, I have major issues with the peer review process currently in that, there appears to be a policy now within some journals to publish anything (the more controversial the better) and as a consequence the review process is less critical and stringent - standards appear to be slipping. This appears more prevalent, in my view, in the commercial publicatiosn as opposed to those produced by socities or professional organisations whose main objectives are not commercial. I would give greater credence to publications from these journals.

column33: Assessment of Intraseasonal to Interannual Climate Prediction and Predictability
Assessment of Sea-Turtle Status and Trends: Integrating Demography and Abundance
Adapting to the Impacts of Climate Change
column85: The most important criterion in selecting references was their relevance to issues addressed by the study topic. When there were multiple references to substantiate a given point, the most robust studies (a function of study design, quality of analysis, quality and clarity of writing, temporal and spatial extent, and degree of synthesis) were the ones cited. The only caveat is that we never cited studies that we didn't know about. Almost certainly there were superb studies with which the study team was unfamiliar. The NRC staff were extremely helpful in pointing out studies that the report authors didn't know about (e.g., analysis of the impact of particular agricultural adaptations on crop yield or water requirement). In other words, I think that the major source of potential bias was gaps in expertise of the author team.

column33: Realizing the Energy Potential of Methane Hydrate for the United States
Review of the Environmental Protection Agency's Draft IRIS Assessment of Tetrachloroethylene
column85: For the last panel on which I served, which evaluated the dry-cleaner solvent tetrachloroethylene, the risk assessment was driven entirely by human health considerations. I suspect that ecotoxicology was not included because of the nature of the use of the substance (dry cleaning operations, largely, and some degreasing), because of the paucity of data for this particular chemical, and because it is volatile and not persistent.  For whatever reason, ecotoxicology never came up and (personally) I think that that represents a significant omission. At the very least, some consideration might have led to the conclusion that we know next to nothing about the ecotoxicological impact of this chemical and should learn more.

column85: The report I worked on was about assessing demographic trends in sea turtles. As many early studies have shown, the information gleaned from a few years of population trends would lead to the conclusion of imminent extinction or population expansion, when the truth from long-term studies is somewhere in the middle. The same is true of many fauna such as sardines and anchovies, which go through huge boom and bust trends. Many ecological processes occur on decadal timescales or longer, and without capturing those trends, it is difficult to make prudent decisions for conservation and management.

column85: Our study was concerned with risk from laboratyr pathogens, and as such, incidence of organisms in the region was more important than any particular short term or long term ecological dynamic.  While I would like to see policy decisions based on longer term planning horizons, the current government gestault does not seem to be capable of this. /  / In terms of which articles we referenced, these were based on our personal knowledge of the literature and their relevance to the questions at hand.  We tried to summarize the current state of scientific knowledge as pertaining to the topic.  Factors like date of publication, authors, journal, et cetera were only indirect correlates.

column85: A general problem encountered in animal ecology-related studies, mainly relating to animal health, is the lack of proper study design and the propensity of many authors to make extraordinary conclusions that go way beyond the data collected, regardless of study length.  There seems to be a sense that long-term studies collecting buckets of observational data make sound for sound science, despit the lack of disciplined methodological approaches to test specific hypotheses. /

column85: Your questions seem focused on duration of studies as a feature to be understood.  Long-term studies in general such as the LTER program have less bang for the buck than well planned and well financed studies with clear objectives.  The information that tends to be in short supply spring from well conceived large area studies.  A significant amount of good information comes from small groups who have been e=involved in a series of studies over time that evolve as part of a discovery process.
